text.p: German Bundesbank president Hans Tietmeyer said on Monday the single European currency would require politicians, companies and wage negotiators across the continent to behave more flexibly.

In an article written for the Tuesday edition of Germany's Handelsblatt newspaper, Tietmeyer said the arrival of the Euro, due in 1999, will mean currency movements will no longer be able to counter-balance varying economic conditions across Europe.
"In particular, fiscal and wage policies must (as a result) be fitted to the demands of currency union and, what's more, over the long-run," he said.
It would be "wishful thinking" for any member of a single currency to believe it could retain independence in its industrial and financial policies within such a union.

Isolated reactions by countries to external events -- such as the oil crisis of the 1970s -- would either run in conflict to wider European monetary policy or damage output and employment in the affected regions, he said.
